SEYMOUR SIEGEL
He’s president of the National As¬
sociation of Educational Broadcasters,
a band of serious radiomen which has
begun a campaign to lure back to ra¬
dio the by-passed audience of serious
listeners who seek stronger cultural
fare than quiz shows and soap operas.
Siegel, who is also director of New
York’s city-owned station, WNYC, has
transcribed literate lectures, adult
plays (King Lear) and high-level musi¬
cal programs. After a year of tentative
operations, the NAEB network has
grown to 51 noncommercial stations. It
has no ambition to compete with com¬
mercial radio but wants to be a “loyal
opposition” providing “other than
trivia and shallow entertainment.”
